The treatment given was chemoradiation (ChemoRT) with a dose of 66 Gy in 60 fractions. The fact that there's no local, regional, or distant recurrence mentioned is positive. Also, no second primary cancer, which is another good sign.

HPV-positive oropharyngeal cancers have higher survival rates. Studies show 3-year overall survival around 80-90% for this group. Even though his stage is III, the absence of smoking and good performance status further improve his prognosis. The chemo would have been cisplatin-based, which is standard. The response to treatment is crucial, and since there's no evidence of recurrence, that's favorable. The contrast-enhanced imaging showing no residual disease would support a good outcome. So putting it all together, the likelihood is that he's alive.
